questions.title: Understanding Array Access Patterns
questions.description: Learn the difference between direct array access and sequential search operations
questions.review:
Key concepts: 
 1) Storing data in an array means we can jump straight to a position in the array 
 2) Array is limited when we don't know the index of the item we are looking for

steps.comment: When data is stored in an array, the computer actually does not know what is stored in each position. It just knows where the array is stored in memory and some basic information (length, slotsize, etc.) about the array.

However, we can use that information to instantly access any index in an array using a formula: 
baseAddress + (index * elementSize).
Let's say our array starts at memory address 100 and each element takes 2 bytes
To access index 3 we apply the formula: baseAddress + (index * elementSize). And the computer calculates: 100 + (3 * 2) = 106
If we want to access index 5, what value will we get using the formula: 100 + (5 * 2)?
This is why array access is instant - no matter the index, we can calculate its exact memory location instantly
However, if we do not know the specific index of an item, we will have to search through the array one by one
We start with the first index (index 0). It is not 25, so we move to the next index (index 1)
On to next element (index 1). It is still not 25
Onto index 2 and we have found 25! Notice how we had to check elements one by one until we found it

While arrays give us instant access when we know the index, the trade-off becomes clear when we need to find specific values - we must resort to checking elements one by one, making our search time depend on the array's size.
In the worst-case scenario when we want to search for 25 (assuming it is in the array), where would it be?
steps.hint: The worst-case scenario is when we have to check every element in the array to find the target

steps.comment: Exactly! In the worst-case scenario, we would have to check every element in the array to find the target, the only worse case is if the target is not in the array at all

questions.title: Understanding Contiguous Memory in Arrays
questions.description: Learn why arrays require continuous memory and the implications for insertions and deletions
questions.review:
Key concepts: 
 1) Array elements must stay together in memory 
2) Inserting/deleting requires shifting elements 
3) Array size must be declared in advance

code: # First check if array is full
# Shift all elements after index to the right
# Shift all elements after index to the left

steps.comment: Let's understand insertion in a fixed-size array. First, we check if there's space in the array.
Trying to insert 25 at position 1. First step: Check if array is full
Array is full! We return false or throw an error so that we don't overwrite existing data.
Let's try again with a non-full array. Since the array length (3) is less than the maxsize (4), we have space to insert the new value.
But index 1, where we want to insert 25, is already occupied by 20
So we have to shift elements right since we have empty space at the end. We start by copying the rightmost element to the empty space.
After copying 30 to the empty space, we can shift 20 to the next position.
After copying 20, we can now safely add 25 to 20's old position
Finally insert 25 at position 1. And we are done!
Now let's learn about deletion. Starting with this array:
Let's delete the element at position 1 (value 25).
The loop starts with the element we were going to delete, where we take the element next to it and copy it back there
After the first loop, what will the array look like?
steps.hint: We are copying elements from the left to the right

steps.comment: Great! Now we do the same for the rest of the array
Now that we have copied 30 over to index 2, what should we do next?
steps.hint: Look at line 20 of the code

steps.comment: That is right! We clear the last element by setting it to None
Let's try a more complex example: delete_multiple_elements([10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60], [1, 3, 5]). Here's our starting array:
After we run this line of code, what will the array look like? Place the remaining numbers in their correct positions.
steps.hint: We are deleting elements at indices 1, 3, and 5

steps.comment: Perfect! Now you understand how multiple deletions work in an array. The remaining elements shift left to fill the gaps.

questions.title: Understanding Dynamic Arrays
questions.description: Learn how dynamic arrays automatically resize to accommodate new elements
questions.review:
Key concepts:
 1) Arrays double in size when full 
2) Amortized O(1) insertion time 
3) Memory is allocated in advance 
4) Arrays shrink when mostly empty

code: # Check if array is at capacity
# Copy all elements to new array
# Shrink array if using less than 25% of capacity

steps.comment: In the last level, we learned that array sizes are fixed, but we can use dynamic arrays to make them more flexible and practical. Let's start with a dynamic array of capacity 4, containing 3 elements:
When we try to append 40, first we check if we're at capacity
Since we still have space, we can directly append 40
Now when we try to append 50, the array is full as we already have 4 elements. Time to resize!
We create a new array with double the capacity (8 spaces)
Copy all existing elements to the new array
Finally, we can append 50 to the resized array
Let's look at pop operations. Starting with this array:
Pop removes the last element (30)
Now we're using < 25% of capacity (2/8), so we'll shrink the array to save memory
Let's try to combine our knowledge and go through an example. Starting with an empty array of capacity 4
After all these operations, what do you think will be the final capacity of the array?
steps.hint: We doubled the capacity when we ran out of space, and we halved the capacity when we had less than 25% of the array used

steps.comment: Great, now let's see if you can place the final elements in their correct positions
Great! Now you know how dynamic arrays work!

levels.description: Learn about linked lists and how to build them step by step.

questions.title: Understanding Linked List Traversal
questions.description: Learn how linked lists store and access data through node connections
questions.review:
Key concepts: 
 1) Linked lists connect nodes through references/pointers 
 2) We must traverse from the head to access any node 
 3) Direct access is not possible like in arrays

steps.comment: A linked list consists of nodes, where each node contains a value and a reference to the next node. Unlike arrays, the nodes can be stored anywhere in memory.
To access any node in a linked list, we must start at the head node. We cannot jump directly to a specific position.
In memory, linked list nodes can be scattered across different locations. Each node stores both its value and a reference to the next node.
To find a node, we must follow the references (arrows) that jump between scattered memory locations. We can't calculate positions like in an array.
This is why linked lists are great for inserting and deleting elements (just update the references), but slower for accessing elements (must traverse from the start).
multipleChoiceAnswers: We can jump directly to any node
We must follow the references from head
We can start from any node
steps.multipleChoiceCorrectAnswer: We must follow the references from head

steps.comment: We use the next reference to move from one node to another. This is how we traverse the list.
When searching for a value, we must check each node one by one until we find it
Let's say we're looking for value 25. We first check the head node (64).
Not found at head, move to next node (34)
Found 25! Notice how we had to traverse through previous nodes to reach it
In the worst-case scenario when searching for a value, where would it be in the linked list?
steps.hint: Consider which position would require checking the most nodes

steps.comment: Correct! The worst case would be searching for a value at the tail of the list, or a value that doesn't exist in the list at all.

questions.title: Understanding Queue Implementation
questions.description: Learn how queues work by watching the code execute and then building your own operations
questions.hint:
Key concepts: 
 1) Front removes elements, Rear adds elements 2) Count tracks number of elements 3) Use modulo (%) for wraparound!
questions.review: Great job! You've mastered how queue operations work with fixed arrays, including empty and full conditions.

steps.comment: Let's understand how FixedQueue works. We start with an empty array of size 5, front at 0, rear at -1, and count at 0
The is_empty() method checks if count is 0. This tells us if there are any elements in the queue
If we add element 'A', what will is_empty() return: True(0) or False(1)?
Let's try to enqueue value 'F' when queue is full. First step: check if queue is full
Since count equals size, is_full() returns True. Will enqueue return True(1) or False(0)?
When enqueue fails, we calculate (rear + 1) % size but never assign it. What would this value be?
We never reach this line when full. The queue remains unchanged with count=5
Let's see what happens when we dequeue. First we check if queue is empty
We remove 'A' from front position and set that slot to None
Front moves to next position. What will (front + 1) % size equal?
After several dequeues, we're at the end. What happens when we dequeue 'E'?
After removing 'E', front will wrap around. What will (front + 1) % size equal?

questions.title: Deleting from a Linked List
questions.description: Learn how to remove a node from a linked list
questions.hint: To delete a node, we need to update the previous node's pointer to skip over the node we want to delete. The skipped node will no longer be part of the list.
questions.review: Well done! You've learned how to delete nodes from a linked list. By updating the pointers to skip a node, we effectively remove it from the list without breaking the chain.

Node is now removed from the list

levels.description: Learn about binary trees and how they organize data hierarchically.

questions.title: Building a Binary Tree
questions.description: Learn how to construct a basic binary tree by adding nodes as left and right children
questions.hint: Each node in a binary tree can have up to two children: a left child and a right child.
questions.review: Excellent! You've learned how to create a basic binary tree structure. Remember that each node can have at most two children.

steps.comment: First, we define our TreeNode class
Create the root node with value 10
Add the left child with value 5
Add the right child with value 15

questions.title: Inserting into a Binary Search Tree
questions.description: Learn how to insert a new node into a binary search tree while maintaining the ordering property
questions.hint: In a binary search tree, values less than a node go to the left, greater values go to the right.
questions.review: Great job! You've learned how to maintain the binary search tree property when inserting new nodes.

Inserting 7: Compare with root (10). Since 7 < 10, go left
7 > 5, so it becomes the right child of 5

questions.title: Tree Traversal
questions.description: Learn how to traverse a binary tree in-order
questions.hint: In-order traversal visits the left subtree, then the current node, then the right subtree.
questions.review: Excellent! You've learned how to perform an in-order traversal of a binary tree.

steps.comment: Start with a binary tree
Visit the leftmost path first
Process nodes in-order: 2, 4, 6, 8, 12
